title: PINATA AUDIO
description1: Instead of using the typical audio-spectrum effects, I shifted into a motion-branding experiment built entirely around Piñata’s visual language using its repeating patterns.
motion-process-par: This wouldn’t behave like a normal audio spectrum as each shape needed its own precise control, instant reactions. Converting the audio, linking every arc to its own driver, and introducing offsets built the foundation.
motion-text-block-1: Using the brand pattern introduced its own complexity: each arc had to be driven by its own null with precise offsets, but sound itself only happens once - you can’t fake “echo” or “motion blur” in audio. That meant every arc needed to move quickly and stop instantly whenever the audio paused, all while staying to the structure of the brand pattern.
motion-text-block-2: The audio’s L & R channels were converted into keyframes onto a single driver null. Each arc’s top point was then linked to its own control null, which was parented to this audio-driven layer. This makes the entire pattern respond to the sound. To add depth, a duplicate of the null shape pairs introduces slight timing offsets, creating a staggered motion.
